summary: This document is an email chain from September 2020 between UK law firm Blackfords LLP and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York. It concerns negotiations over obtaining evidence from the firm's client, who is associated with Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, regarding the period 1994-1997. The client is willing to provide a confidential witness statement but resists a formal interview as they are considered a 'subject' of the investigation.

persons.name: Gary Bloxsome
persons.context: UK solicitor representing an unnamed client associated with Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein. He is negotiating the terms under which his client will provide evidence to the U.S. prosecution.

persons.name: Daniel Cundy
persons.context: UK solicitor who sent reference materials (legal extracts) to the U.S. prosecutors, supporting the firm's position on legal protections for their client.

persons.name: Jennifer Richardson
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, copied on the correspondence regarding the evidence negotiations.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Subject of the U.S. criminal proceedings (US v. Ghislaine Maxwell). The evidence being sought relates to her and Jeffrey Epstein during the indictment period of 1994-1997.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and associate of Ghislaine Maxwell. The evidence being sought relates to the client's association with and knowledge of him.

The client has an association with Ghislaine Maxwell and possesses knowledge relevant to her prosecution.

They are engaged in professional correspondence and negotiations regarding the provision of evidence from Bloxsome's client to the U.S. prosecution.
Partners at the same law firm (Blackfords LLP) working on the same matter for their client.

events.title: Indictment Period for US v. Ghislaine Maxwell

locations: Old Bailey, London EC4M 7EF (Blackfords LLP office)
Southern District of New York (jurisdiction of the prosecution)
keyFacts: A UK law firm is representing an unnamed client who has an association with Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein and possesses relevant knowledge for the U.S. prosecution.

The client is willing to provide a confidential witness statement limited to the 1994-1997 period but refuses a formal interview because U.S. authorities regard him as a 'subject' of the investigation, not just a witness.
The negotiations involve multiple conference calls in July and August 2020, highlighting the cross-jurisdictional complexity of gathering evidence.
The UK solicitors cite U.S. case law (United States v. Allen, Kastigar v. United States) and UK regulatory manuals to argue for strict confidentiality and limited use of any statement provided.
The document reveals prosecutorial efforts to secure evidence from associates of Maxwell and Epstein located outside the United States.
